docs.text: Title: Exp 389 Extract SUMOEu1-GFPnanobody and BirA biotin ligase ¶ Date: "2021-09-14" ¶ Goal ¶ Extract SUMOEu1-GFPnanobody and BirA biotin ligase Issue ¶ Extract SUMOEu1-GFPnanobody and BirA biotin ligase #68 Background ¶ Rasi purified GFPnanobody and Biotin ligase previously , but lost it during cleanup after biotinylation. HPark also purifed GFPnanobody and Biotin ligase in the exp370 ( Purify SUMOEu1-GFPnanobody and BirA biotin ligase #174 ) but due to the Protease contamination GFPnanobody were cut. Here I want to purify both proteins again to get more amount of intact ones. Strategy ¶ We follow same strategy as what we did for RT/APOBEC1 extraction in the Exp 381 Extract SSIV-RT and APOBEC1-antiGFP-nanobody Grow ecHPHS290 (NEB-Express Iq + pHPHS244 (pTP264): Biotin ligase BirA) and ecHPHS291 (NEB-Express Iq + pHPHS245 (pTP396): anti-GFP nanobody) in 6 ml of SuperBroth + 1xKan at 37C, 200rpm for overnight. In the morning, dilute them in 50 fold into 300 ml of SuperBroth in 1l flask at 18C Strong lab shaker. After ~6 hours add 300ul of 1M IPTG into each culture and grow them under the same coondition for ~18-19 hours. By using 2ml (total 4ml after well mix) new Ni2+-NTA, purify SSIV-RT and APOBEC1-anti-nanobody. Check them in Coomasie gel. Don't need FPLC Change buffer to the storage buffer and concentrate proteins by using a "Sartorius Vivaspin Turbo 15 Centrifugal Concentrators, MWCO: 30,000 d" Procedure ¶ Extract SUMOEu1-GFPnanobody and BirA biotin ligase ¶ DONE [2021-09-16 Thu]-[2021-09-17 Fri] Cultures ¶ [2021-09-14 Tue] Streak ecHPHS290 and ecHPHS291 on fresh LB+Kan plates and incubate them at 37C for overnight. [2021-09-15 wed] Grow ecHPHS290 (NEB-Express Iq + pHPHS244 (pTP264): Biotin ligase BirA) and ecHPHS291 (NEB-Express Iq + pHPHS245 (pTP396): anti-GFP nanobody) in 2x 3 ml of SuperBroth + 1xKan at 37C, roller drum for overnight [2pm-]. 389_1: ecHPHS290 (BirA) 389_2: ecHPHS291 (GFPnb) In the morning on [2021-09-16 Thu] dilute them in 50 fold into 300 ml of SuperBroth in 1l flask at 18C, 200rpm, Strong lab shaker [11am-5pm]. After ~6 hours add 300ul of 1M IPTG into each culture and grow them under the same condition for ~18-19 hours [5pm-10am]. Made new 2ml of 1M IPTG filtered with 0.22um. [2021-09-17 Fri] Spin down in 2x 500mL bottle 4000rpm, 25 min, 4C. Discard supernatant. Resuspend cell pellets in 1x 25ml of 1x lysis buffer. DONE [2021-09-17 Fri] Prepare protein samples for purification: His Tag ¶ [2021-09-15 Wed] Make 2X Lysis/Elusion buffer: Final Concentration 500 ml 200 ml M.W / Stock solution 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5 50 ml 20 ml 1M Tris pH 7.5 300 mM KCl 22.38 g 8.95 g 74.6 Water to final volume 500 ml 200 ml [2021-09-15 Wed] Make 2X storage buffer: Final Concentration 500 ml 200 ml M.W / Stock solution 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5 50 ml 20ml 1M Tris pH 7.5 100 mM KCl 7.5 g 3 g 74.6 Water to final volume 500 ml 200ml Note: Before stroing samples add 1mM DTT. [2021-09-17 Fri] Make lysis buffer: Make 200 ml Final Concentration 500 ml 200 ml M.W / Stock solution 2X stock 250 ml 100 ml 2x 20 mM Imidazole 0.68 g 272 mg 68 1 mM DTT 500 ul 200 ul 154: 1 M (154 mg in 1ml of RN-H2O) 1 mM PMSF 500 ul 200 ul 174: 1 M (174 mg in 1ml of DMSO) H2O to 500 ml to 200 ml [2021-09-17 Fri] Make elution buffer: make 50 ml Elution buffer 50ml Molecular weight 2x stock 25ml 500mM Imidazole 1.7 g 68 H2O To 50ml Thaw frozen pellets from -80C in iced water for 30 minutes. We directly spin down cell cultures. So skip this step. Spin down cells in 4000rpm for 25 minutes. Dump supernatants. Resuspend cell pellets in 15ml of lysis buffer. Put cells in a metal can and keep it in the small ice bath. Lyse by sonication (6-10x30s pulsing in 50ml conical in an ice-water bath, with 30s cooling in between, Macro-Tip at 100% amplitude, Sonifier in gel cutting room). Clean sonication tip by ddH2O before using new sample Transfer them in a new 50mL tubes (Lysate). Clear lysate by centrifugation for 45 min at 17,000g and 4˚C in the new centrifuge in Roland's lab. We can directly load the lysate as 2x 15ml in 50ml regular Falcon tubes. Move the supernatant to a fresh 50ml tube. Get two binding tubes from Strong lab and stand. Mix well Ni2+-NTA from 4C and put ~15ml of them into each binidng tube. Flow trough the ethanol. Then lysis buffer ~15ml into the column (Poly-Prep Chromatography Columns: Bio-Rad Cat# 731-1550) to wash beads. Close knob of the binding tubes and add little volume of 1x lysis buffer and transfer whole volume of beads into a new 50ml tubes and add supernatant of samples. Incubate them at 4C rotator for 30 minutes. Add lysates into the column and wait until all liquid is gone: Flowthrough (FT). Wash with three column volumes of lysis buffer (A1_2/B1_2/C1_2) before elution (E1_2) with 15ml of elution buffer with 500mM imidazole. Repeat this 3 times. Keep FT1_2/A1_2/B1_2/C1_2/E1_2 at 4C. Keep small volumes (20ul in 4C) of lysate and flowtrhough from 1/2/3 wash steps. I kept 20ul of each samples in the PCR tubes for Coomasie stain. Measure concentrations: E1: A280=0.429 E2: A280=0.368 TODO [2021-09-20 Mon] Coomasie gel ¶ Add the same volum (20ul) of 2x sample buffer to the samples and heat them at 95C for 5 minutes. Run gel at 180V for 50 minutes. Stain with Commassie for ~60 minutes. Wash the gel by ddH2O for 1 hours. Change water every 5 minutes. Take images DONE [2021-09-17 Fri] Concentrate extracted proteins ¶ Transfer E1/E2 into new "Sartorius Vivaspin Turbo 15 Centrifugal Concentrators, MWCO: 30,000 d", respectively and spin down them at 4000g for 30 minutes. Today I did spin down for 10/5 min repeat Note: After 10min or 15 min all sample from the top flew through. Keep the FT in ice for in case I lost proteins during concentrating. Add 2x storage buffer to the top and spin down again under the same condition for 60 minutes. I spin 5 or 10 min. Add 2x storage buffer ~13-14ml to the top again then spin down again. Sample 1 has ~1.4 ml in the top. Sample 2 has ~1.2 ml in the top. Add the same volume of 100% glycerol. Add the same volume 100% glycerol and add 1ul 1M DTT into 1ml of samples. Measure A280 BirA: A280 = 0.395 mg/ml GFPnb: A280 = ~ 0 mg/ml Results: I lost a lot of proteins during concentrating. I think "Sartorius Vivaspin Turbo 15 Centrifugal Concentrators, MWCO: 30,000 d" is too big to capture both proteins. So I decided to use "Genesee Scientific Centrifugal Filters, 10,000 MWCO" with the Flow-Through from above concentration. DONE [2021-09-17 Fri] Concentrate again by using a Concentrator Filter 10,000 MWCO with Flow-Through from the previous concentration ¶ Transfer Flow-Through from the above concentrating procedure into new "Genesee Scientific Centrifugal Filters, 10,000 MWCO", respectively and spin down them at 4000g for 25 minutes. Got ~1 ml in the top. Measured the concentration and both have A280~4.5 mg/ml. So this seem to work form the Flow-Through and this new concentrator. Add 2x storage buffer (~13.5 ml) to the top and spin down again under the same condition for 40 minutes. Repeat this. Add the same volume of 100% glycerol. Add the same volume 100% glycerol and add 1ul 1M DTT into 1ml of samples. Measure A280: Before adding glycerol BirA: A280 = 2.978 mg/ml (~1.2 ml) GFPnb: A280 = 4.729mg/ml (~0.9 ml) Measure A280: After adding glycerol BirA: A280 = 1.746 mg/ml (~2.2 ml) GFPnb: A280 = 2.70 mg/ml (~0.9 ml) DONE [2021-10-06 Wed] Make small aliquotes ¶ Make small aliquotes and save them at -80C Rasi Protein Box2 Aliquotes BirA: A280 = 1.746 mg/ml (4x ~500 ul) GFPnb: A280 = 2.70 mg/ml (4x ~200 ul) DONE [2021-09-20 Mon] Biotinylation ¶ Make 25ml of 2X biotinylation buffer: I will make 50ml Final Volume 25 ml Volume 50ml Stock 2x Storage 24.5ml 49 ml 1M TrisHCl pH 7.5 12.5mM MgCl2 625µl 1.25 ml 1M MgCl2 Note: Add 12.5mM MgCl2 into the 2x storage buffer I already above and use it as 2x biotinylation buffer. Instead of 100mM NaCl (from th eoriginal protocol), we use 100mM KCl Make 25ml of 1X biotinylation buffer by mixing 12.5ml of the above 2X buffer with 12.5ml of H2O. Save the remaining 2X buffer for storage at the end. Make 50mM D-biotin solution by mixing 12.2mg of D-biotin in 1ml of DMSO. Store at -20C for future use (Store such protein purification reagents in a box so that you can find them easily). After you elute the BirA and GFP-nanobody from the Ni-NTA beads, mix 1:50 (today we try 1:10) molar ratio of BirA:GFPnanobody. Protein size A280 (no glycerol) Volume (no glycerol) Corrected Conc. Molarity add V (1:50) add V (1:10) BirA 48.9 kDa 2.978 mg/ml ~1.2 ml 2.889 mg/ml 90.9 uM 27.7 ul 138.5 ul GFPnb 31.8 kDa 4.729 mg/ml ~0.9 ml 4.445 mg/ml 139.9 uM 900 ul 900 ul Exchange to 1ml of the 1X biotinylation buffer using the 10kD concentrator ("Genesee Scientific Centrifugal Filters, 10,000 MWCO" 50ml tube) . Do this by first concentrating the BirA:GFPnanobody mix to 1ml by spinning 4000g 10 min (or more as required), then adding maximum amount of the biotinylation buffer and concentrating back to 1ml. We can repeat this concentration step again once more if you have time. Spin down for 40min: got 1.5ml in the top. Add ~14ml of 2x Biotinylation buffer and spin again for 70 minutes to get ~1ml in the top. Add 20µl of 100mM ATP (Rasi's -80C RRL box) and 5µl of 50mM D-biotin stock into ~1ml of sample and then mix well. Incubate it at 4C for overnight with gentle rotation [~19 hours]. Incubate at 25C for 3 hours with gentle rotation. In the morning add 20ul of 100mM ATP again and incubate it at 25C (room T) for 3 hours (11:30am-2:30pm) with gentle rotation. Exchange with the 2X storage buffer (without MgCl2) using the 10kD concentrator above twice and bring down to 1ml. Check concentration using A280 and calculate 1.569 mg/ml. Add equal volume of 100% glycerol. Add 1ul of 1M DTT per 1 ml sample. Measure A280 = 0.844 mg/ml. Aliquote 9x 200ul (168.8 ug in 200 ul aliquote) and keep it in the Rasi's Working Protein Box 1 at -80C

Keep small volumes (20ul in 4C) of lysate and flowtrhough from 1/2/3 wash steps. I kept 20ul of each samples in the PCR tubes for Coomasie stain. Measure concentrations: E1: A280=0.429 E2: A280=0.368
docs.title: DONE [2021-09-17 Fri] Prepare protein samples for purification: His Tag

docs.text: Add the same volum (20ul) of 2x sample buffer to the samples and heat them at 95C for 5 minutes. Run gel at 180V for 50 minutes. Stain with Commassie for ~60 minutes. Wash the gel by ddH2O for 1 hours. Change water every 5 minutes. Take images
docs.title: TODO [2021-09-20 Mon] Coomasie gel

docs.text: Transfer E1/E2 into new "Sartorius Vivaspin Turbo 15 Centrifugal Concentrators, MWCO: 30,000 d", respectively and spin down them at 4000g for 30 minutes. Today I did spin down for 10/5 min repeat Note: After 10min or 15 min all sample from the top flew through. Keep the FT in ice for in case I lost proteins during concentrating. Add 2x storage buffer to the top and spin down again under the same condition for 60 minutes. I spin 5 or 10 min. Add 2x storage buffer ~13-14ml to the top again then spin down again. Sample 1 has ~1.4 ml in the top. Sample 2 has ~1.2 ml in the top. Add the same volume of 100% glycerol. Add the same volume 100% glycerol and add 1ul 1M DTT into 1ml of samples. Measure A280 BirA: A280 = 0.395 mg/ml GFPnb: A280 = ~ 0 mg/ml Results: I lost a lot of proteins during concentrating. I think "Sartorius Vivaspin Turbo 15 Centrifugal Concentrators, MWCO: 30,000 d" is too big to capture both proteins. So I decided to use "Genesee Scientific Centrifugal Filters, 10,000 MWCO" with the Flow-Through from above concentration.
docs.title: DONE [2021-09-17 Fri] Concentrate extracted proteins

docs.text: Transfer Flow-Through from the above concentrating procedure into new "Genesee Scientific Centrifugal Filters, 10,000 MWCO", respectively and spin down them at 4000g for 25 minutes. Got ~1 ml in the top. Measured the concentration and both have A280~4.5 mg/ml. So this seem to work form the Flow-Through and this new concentrator. Add 2x storage buffer (~13.5 ml) to the top and spin down again under the same condition for 40 minutes. Repeat this. Add the same volume of 100% glycerol. Add the same volume 100% glycerol and add 1ul 1M DTT into 1ml of samples. Measure A280: Before adding glycerol BirA: A280 = 2.978 mg/ml (~1.2 ml) GFPnb: A280 = 4.729mg/ml (~0.9 ml) Measure A280: After adding glycerol BirA: A280 = 1.746 mg/ml (~2.2 ml) GFPnb: A280 = 2.70 mg/ml (~0.9 ml)
docs.title: DONE [2021-09-17 Fri] Concentrate again by using a Concentrator Filter 10,000 MWCO with Flow-Through from the previous concentration

docs.text: Make small aliquotes and save them at -80C Rasi Protein Box2 Aliquotes BirA: A280 = 1.746 mg/ml (4x ~500 ul) GFPnb: A280 = 2.70 mg/ml (4x ~200 ul)
docs.title: DONE [2021-10-06 Wed] Make small aliquotes

docs.text: Make 25ml of 2X biotinylation buffer: I will make 50ml Final Volume 25 ml Volume 50ml Stock 2x Storage 24.5ml 49 ml 1M TrisHCl pH 7.5 12.5mM MgCl2 625µl 1.25 ml 1M MgCl2 Note: Add 12.5mM MgCl2 into the 2x storage buffer I already above and use it as 2x biotinylation buffer. Instead of 100mM NaCl (from th eoriginal protocol), we use 100mM KCl Make 25ml of 1X biotinylation buffer by mixing 12.5ml of the above 2X buffer with 12.5ml of H2O. Save the remaining 2X buffer for storage at the end. Make 50mM D-biotin solution by mixing 12.2mg of D-biotin in 1ml of DMSO. Store at -20C for future use (Store such protein purification reagents in a box so that you can find them easily). After you elute the BirA and GFP-nanobody from the Ni-NTA beads, mix 1:50 (today we try 1:10) molar ratio of BirA:GFPnanobody. Protein size A280 (no glycerol) Volume (no glycerol) Corrected Conc. Molarity add V (1:50) add V (1:10) BirA 48.9 kDa 2.978 mg/ml ~1.2 ml 2.889 mg/ml 90.9 uM 27.7 ul 138.5 ul GFPnb 31.8 kDa 4.729 mg/ml ~0.9 ml 4.445 mg/ml 139.9 uM 900 ul 900 ul Exchange to 1ml of the 1X biotinylation buffer using the 10kD concentrator ("Genesee Scientific Centrifugal Filters, 10,000 MWCO" 50ml tube) . Do this by first concentrating the BirA:GFPnanobody mix to 1ml by spinning 4000g 10 min (or more as required), then adding maximum amount of the biotinylation buffer and concentrating back to 1ml. We can repeat this concentration step again once more if you have time. Spin down for 40min: got 1.5ml in the top. Add ~14ml of 2x Biotinylation buffer and spin again for 70 minutes to get ~1ml in the top. Add 20µl of 100mM ATP (Rasi's -80C RRL box) and 5µl of 50mM D-biotin stock into ~1ml of sample and then mix well. Incubate it at 4C for overnight with gentle rotation [~19 hours]. Incubate at 25C for 3 hours with gentle rotation. In the morning add 20ul of 100mM ATP again and incubate it at 25C (room T) for 3 hours (11:30am-2:30pm) with gentle rotation. Exchange with the 2X storage buffer (without MgCl2) using the 10kD concentrator above twice and bring down to 1ml. Check concentration using A280 and calculate 1.569 mg/ml. Add equal volume of 100% glycerol. Add 1ul of 1M DTT per 1 ml sample. Measure A280 = 0.844 mg/ml. Aliquote 9x 200ul (168.8 ug in 200 ul aliquote) and keep it in the Rasi's Working Protein Box 1 at -80C
docs.title: DONE [2021-09-20 Mon] Biotinylation

docs.text: Title: Exp422 Extract RT and TadA-XTEN48-antiGFP-nanobody ¶ Date: "2022-02-01" ¶ Goal ¶ Extract RT and TadA-XTEN48-antiGFP-nanobody Issue ¶ Extract RT and TadA-XTEN48-antiGFP-nanobody Strategy ¶ Procedure ¶ Extract RT/TadA-XTEN48-antiGFP-nanobody ¶ DONE [2022-02-24 Thu] Cultures ¶ Grow ecHPHS344-2/pHPHS536-1 in 5 ml of SuperBroth + 1xKan at 37C, 200rpm for overnight [4:25pm-12:50pm]. In the morning dilute them in 50 fold into 250 ml of SuperBroth in 1l flask at 18C Strong lab shaker. After ~5 hours [12:50pm-5:50pm] add 300ul of 1M IPTG into each culture and grow them under the same coondition for ~18-19 hours [~18 hours]. Spin down in 1L bottle 4000rpm, 25 min, 4C. Discard supernatant. Resuspend cell pellets in 1x 25ml of 1x lysis buffer. Label: 1: RT (pHPHS344-2) 2: TadA-XTEN48-antiGFP-nanobody (pHPHS536-1) Prepare protein samples for purification: I will use I made before keeping at 4C. ¶ Make 2X Lysis/Elusion buffer: Final Concentration M.W / Stock solution 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5 50 ml 20ml 1M Tris pH 7.5 300 mM KCl 22.38 g g 74.6 Water to final volume 500 ml 200ml Make 2X storage buffer: Final Concentration M.W / Stock solution 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5 50 ml 20ml 1M Tris pH 7.5 100 mM KCl 7.5 g g 74.6 Water to final volume 500 ml 200ml Note: Before stroing samples add 1mM DTT. Make lysis buffer: Make 200 ml Final Concentration 500 ml M.W / Stock solution 2X stock 250 ml 2x 20 mM Imidazole 0.68 g 68 1 mM DTT 500 ul 1 M (154 mg in 1 ml of dH2O) 1 mM PMSF 500 ul 1 M (174 mg in 1ml of DMSO) H2O to 500 ml Make elution buffer: make 50 ml Elution buffer 50ml Molecular weight 2x stock 25ml 500mM Imidazole 1.7 g 68 H2O To 50ml Thaw frozen pellets from -80C in iced water for 30 minutes. We directly spin down cell cultures. So skip this step. Spin down cells in 4000rpm for 25 minutes. Dump supernatants. Resuspend cell pellets in 15ml of lysis buffer. Put cells in a metal can and keep it in the small ice bath. Lyse by sonication (6-10x30s pulsing in 50ml conical in an ice-water bath, with 30s cooling in between, Macro-Tip at 100% amplitude, Sonifier in gel cutting room). Clean sonication tip by ddH2O before using new sample Transfer them in a new 50mL tubes (Lysate). Clear lysate by centrifugation for 45 min at 17,000g and 4˚C in the new centrifuge in Roland's lab. We can directly load the lysate as 2x 15ml in 50ml regular Falcon tubes. Move the supernatant to a fresh 50ml tube. Combined the supernatant. We use one tube for each sample so don't need to combine. Get two binding tubes from Strong lab and stand. Mix well Ni2+-NTA from 4C and put ~2ml of them into each binidng tube. Flow trough the ethanol. I use two binidng tube I bought. Then lysis buffer ~15ml into the column (Poly-Prep Chromatography Columns: Bio-Rad Cat# 731-1550) to wash beads. Close knob of the binding tubes and add little volume of 1x lysis buffer and transfer whole volume of beads into a new 50ml tubes and add supernatant of samples. Incubate them at 4C rotator for 30 minutes. Add lysates into the column and wait until all liquid is gone: Flowthrough (FD). Wash with three column volumes of lysis buffer (A1_2/B1_2/C1_2) before elution (E1_2) with 15ml of elution buffer with 500mM imidazole. Repeat this 3 times. Keep FT/A1_2/B1_2/c1_2/E1_2 at 4C. Keep small volumes (20ul in 4C) of lysate and flowtrhough from 1/2/3 wash steps. I kept 30ul of each samples in the PCR tubes for Coomasie stain on [2022-02-28 Mon]. DONE [2022-02-25 Fri] Concentrate extracted proteins ¶ Transfer E1/E2 into two new "Sartorius Vivaspin Turbo 15 Centrifugal Concentrators, MWCO: 30,000 (for RT) and 10,000 (for tadA)" and spin down them at 4000g for 10 minutes. Once 0.5ml of sample is remained in the top part, add 2x storage buffer ~15ml then spin down again at 4000g for 10 minutes. Repeat the above to exchange buffer. Add the same volume 100% glycerol and 1ul of 1M DTT into 1ml of samples. Aliquote 10x 100 ul and keep them at -80C except one at -20C. 6 Concentrations: 1 (RT): 0.683 mg/ml (92.9k Da) 2 (TadA): 0.053 mg/ml (55.2k Da) TODO [2022-02-28 Mon] Coomasie gel ¶ Add the same volum (20ul) of 2x sample buffer to the samples and heat them at 95C for 5 minutes. Run gel at 180V for 50 minutes. Stain with Commassie for ~60 minutes. Wash the gel by ddH2O for 1 hours. Change water every 5 minutes. Take images Label (Left to right): L1/FT1/A1/B1/C1/E1/Concentrated1(1/5 dilution), ladder, L2/FT2/A2/B2/C2/E2/Concentrated2

docs.text: How Illumina sequencing works: https://bioinformatics-core-shared-training.github.io/cruk-summer-school-2017/Day1/Session4-seqIntro.html Matreyek lab dual indexing description Succinct description of how Illumina sequencing works for different flow cell designs, with a specific focus on custom sequencing and index read primer. Amplicon sequencing detailed information from Norwegian Sequencing Center Describes the minimum sequence requirements for custom paired end sequencing design. Note the extra sequence necessary at the P5 end for paired-end sequencing. In NextSeq, Read 1 and Read 2 primers are pooled before loading. The two index primers (i5 and i7) are pooled before loading. The first base of Read 1 sequencing should not be a G or a T since both of these are dark.
docs.title: Notes on illumina sequencing

docs.text: General usage of Leica microscope + troubleshooting tips ¶ Turning on the scope: Turn on microscope, air pump, light source, laser source (all 4 are under the desk), as well as the CO2/air-temp thing (connected altogether with one switch) on the table to the side (5 components total) Wait a few seconds before turning on the next component Then turn on the camera. Since the camera is the most sensitive, we turn on all other components first. Turn on computer and login Micro-Manager 1.4 Use the most recent config settings (currently 2019) Power-cycle LED bars on main micro-manager dialogue box Turning off the scope: Turn off the 4 components under the scope and the CO2 box to the side, then turn off the camera Follow instructions here for transferring images or turning on linux ssh to transfer later Troubleshooting: Tony: Tony.Cooke@leica-microsystems.com, +12063272314 COM errors These error messages typically appear when attempting to load a config file in MicroManager at startup and indicates a connection error between computer and one of the 6 components. This can typically be addressed by power-cycling all 6 components and computer then trying again. It is important not to move or disconnect any USB connections on any of the devices! This will break the connection to the computer and cause a COM error. If a disrupted USB connection is the cause of the COM error, you may see additional error messages regarding a "Serial Port" or "VCP" being unavailable in the Hardware Configuration Wizard. Contact Tony to fix.
docs.title: General usage of Leica microscope + troubleshooting tips

Since the camera is the most sensitive, we turn on all other components first. Turn on computer and login Micro-Manager 1.4 Use the most recent config settings (currently 2019) Power-cycle LED bars on main micro-manager dialogue box Turning off the scope: Turn off the 4 components under the scope and the CO2 box to the side, then turn off the camera Follow instructions here for transferring images or turning on linux ssh to transfer later Troubleshooting: Tony: Tony.Cooke@leica-microsystems.com, +12063272314 COM errors These error messages typically appear when attempting to load a config file in MicroManager at startup and indicates a connection error between computer and one of the 6 components. This can typically be addressed by power-cycling all 6 components and computer then trying again. It is important not to move or disconnect any USB connections on any of the devices! This will break the connection to the computer and cause a COM error. If a disrupted USB connection is the cause of the COM error, you may see additional error messages regarding a "Serial Port" or "VCP" being unavailable in the Hardware Configuration Wizard. Contact Tony to fix.

docs.text: Goal ¶ Based on the manual for the Plasma Cleaner/Plasmaflo/Vacuum-pump, here I develope a simple protocol for how to use the Plasma-Cleaner to bond PDMS-microfluidic device to cover-glass. Procedure ¶ Safety information ¶ The Plasma Cleaner is an electrical instrument: to avoid electric shock, plase observe all standard precautions, such as not operating the device near water and operating the device at appropriate libne voltage and frequency. Do not remove panels or housing, except by a certified electronics technician. Do not use the Plasma Cleaner front door when the chamber is under vacuum. Do not use the Plasma Cleaner near flammable materials. Do not plug vacuum pumps whose input electrical current requirement exceeds 7 Amps into the Plasma Cleaner rear vacuum outlet. With respect to vacuum pumps, please refer to the pump user's manual for specific precautions. If oxygen is used as the process gas in concentrations near or above its flammability thresgold, an oxygen service pump must be used. If corrosove gasses are used, make sure the seals and gas connection materials are compatible with the gas. Use a suatable vacuum pump to sercvice corrosove gases. If toxic gases or gases that ionize to toxic products or intermedeiates are usd, the gases must be properly purged from the chamber prior to venting and the pump exhaust must br properly vented. For safe gas handling prcedures specific to your process gas, contact your process gas supplier. Evacuating the chamber ¶ Turn on the Plasma Cleaner main power. Put the sample in the chamber: On the top of small petri-dish, I put one coverglass and one chip with the pattern side-up. Check that the 3-way valve is clesed (level is vertical, manual Figure 12C). Close and hold the front door against the chamber. Turn on the vacuum pump. The vacuum will hold the front door in place. Evacuate the chamber for 1-3 minutes or to the desired vacuum pressure. Inputing gas ¶ Open the 3-way vlave to air or gas (lever points to the metering valve, Figure 12A). Generating plasma ¶ Select the desired RF power level: Used "low" mode today. Look through the viewing window for the plasma glow and indication that plasma has formed . If needed, adjust the metering valve slightly until the plasma intensity is visibly maximized. This broadly corresponds to optimal plasma generation conditions. Plasma treatment ¶ Process the sample for the desired duration. The timing of the plasmia treatment should begin when the plasma glow is first observed. I used \~1 minute. At the end of the process, turn off the RF power. Allow 1-3 minutes for the vacuum pump to evacuate any residual process gas from the chamber. Close the 3-way vlave (lever is vertical, Figure 12C). Venting the chamber ¶ Turn off the vacuum pump. Slowly open the 3-way valve to vent (lever points to vent, Figure 12B). Once atmospheric pressure is reached, close the 3-way valve (lever is vertical, Figure 12C). Turn off the Plasma Cleaner main power. Open the front ddor and remove the sample. Notes ¶ Here I do not use the PlasmaFlo For the protocol with the PlasmaFlo, see the manual again. Bonding chips ¶ Follow the short protocol without using PlasmaFlo and by only using air, I bonded one 4-channel and one 1-channel chip on the cover-glases. Bake the bonded chip on the hot plate for \~30 minutes. 80 ℃ expected but I realized the plate temperature was \~85 ℃.
docs.title: Using plasma cleaner for bonding microfludicts

docs.text: Goal: Make Carbenicillin stock solution. ¶ To prepare a 100mg /1ml stock solution of carbenicillin. ¶ Carbenicillin : 10 mL (1,000 X Stock) Reagents needed: ¶ 1 g carbenicillin disodium salt 10 ml DNase/RNase-Free Water Directions: ¶ Make labeling stickers on the top of the Microfuge Tubes 1.5mL (ex. Carb 100mg/ml 1/31/2019) To prepare a 100mg/ml of carbenicillin. Measuring in the Nano Weight Scale.(Be careful, it's dangerous!) Dissolve 1g of disodium carbenicillin in 9ml of H2O.(UltraPure DNase/RNase-Free Water ) Top up the volume to 10 ml (use 17ml tube) Filter-sterilize using a 0.22-μm filter.(Syringe Filtration https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M__bFPnmVcE or https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7b_JFsL2bXo ) Prepare a syringe Draw a small amount of air(This air used to purge the filter ensuring maximum sample throughout) Load the sample into the syringe Attach the filter securely with a twisting motion. Press the syringe plunger gently Push the air through the filter to recover any remaining sample Store in 1ml aliquots at -20°C.( 100mg/ ml x 10 Microfuge Tubes ) use a filter tip from the hood area. Use at 1:1000 dilution in LB or LB-Agar. Safety Information ¶ Symbol: GHS08 Signal word: Danger!!! Personal Protective Equipment: dust mask type N95, Eyeshields, Faceshields, Gloves
docs.title: Goal: Make Carbenicillin stock solution.

docs.text: Make labeling stickers on the top of the Microfuge Tubes 1.5mL (ex. Carb 100mg/ml 1/31/2019) To prepare a 100mg/ml of carbenicillin. Measuring in the Nano Weight Scale.(Be careful, it's dangerous!) Dissolve 1g of disodium carbenicillin in 9ml of H2O.(UltraPure DNase/RNase-Free Water ) Top up the volume to 10 ml (use 17ml tube) Filter-sterilize using a 0.22-μm filter.(Syringe Filtration https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M__bFPnmVcE or https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7b_JFsL2bXo ) Prepare a syringe Draw a small amount of air(This air used to purge the filter ensuring maximum sample throughout) Load the sample into the syringe Attach the filter securely with a twisting motion. Press the syringe plunger gently Push the air through the filter to recover any remaining sample Store in 1ml aliquots at -20°C.( 100mg/ ml x 10 Microfuge Tubes ) use a filter tip from the hood area. Use at 1:1000 dilution in LB or LB-Agar.

docs.text: Preparing chemically competent E. coli for high efficiency transformations ¶ Purpose ¶ To make a large lab stock of chemically competent E. coli cells for routine plasmid cloning. We typically use `NEB-Stable` cells ( ecAS4 ) for cloning in our lab. Materials ¶ Transformation Buffer SOB Medium shaker. Procedure ¶ [2019-02-18 Mon] Day 0: Plate `NEB-Stable` cells (ecAS4.1) from -80°C Stock on LB plates(use a tip to spread) and incubate at 37°C, 18-20 hours. [2019-02-19 Tue] Day 1: Start overnights of a single colony of the strain, LB, *37°C *, 5 ml, 200rpm, 12–16 hours(or over night, keep it in warm room). (hint: use a tip to spread in culture tube) [2019-02-20 Wed] Day 2: Dilute by 20 fold (250 μl) in new LB 5 ml, keep in the culture tube in the Shaking Water Bath (23 °C or room temp, 200 rpm, 7-8 hours) Day 2: Check OD600= \~0.4-0.5 is OK. And then dilute again, 1:1000 into 100ml of SOB medium, 23°C , 200 rpm, 1L flask, 15 hours. leave a note(day,time and name) for a shaking machine) (hint - use a Clear Glass Shake Flasks w/ 3 Baffles. It's more efficiency. 16°C gives better transformation efficiency. leave a note(day,time and name) for a shaking machine) <2019-02-21 Thu> Day 3: prepare in cool room 2 white tray with ice. (one is for cool down a shaking flask, and one is for 50μl aliquots + 4 tip yellow racks) 1 ice bucket (for 4 centrifuge bottles ) Chill 2×50ml (pre-chilled 50ml Falcon tubes on ice bucket) 10 ml glass pipettes and pipette bucket automatic pipette (for 1250μl) multi pipette and tips (for 200μl) 2 beakers (one is for liquid dump, one is for the used tip.) Box to keep in −80°C.(keep in cool) Day 3: Check OD again. When culture hits OD600=0.4-0.5 (we had \~0.67), rapidly chill your cultures by placing them in an ice-water batch for 10 min and swirling them occasionally. Pour,divide 4 bottles and put the bottles in a centrifuge. (4000 rpm, 4°, 20 min) (hint - turn on the powder and start the centrifuge for cool down before use, 4000 rpm, 4°C, 10 min) check a liquid level,it must be simillar volume. It's going to a centrifuge. Bring the bottles and pour off supernatant.( Keep the bottles on the ice bucket) Add 20 ml Transfomation Buffer(TB) per each bottle by pipetting. Move to 50 ml falcon tube. Chill cells in ice-water bath for another 10 min. Make sure that the centrifuge is cold. Do centrifuge again. Spin down cells 4000 rpm, 20 min, 4°C. Pour off supernatant. Add 5 ml of ice-cold TB. Bring up final volume to 8.3 ml and add 600 μl of molecular biology grade DMSO. (So. Total volume is 8.9 ml) Mix well gently by pipetting and leave on ice for 10 min. Aliquot 100 μl into pre-chilled PCR strip tubes with individual caps and freeze immediately in vapor phase of Liquid N2 (but we don't use this). Transfer to -80°C. Add label on the box. (title, date, name)

docs.text: [2019-03-05 Tue] SCD-His Agar Plates (2 Sleeves) ¶ Prepare 1000ml bottle. Put the bottle on a magnet sir bar on Magnetic Stirrer. Add 800ml ddH2O + 20g of Dextrose + 20g of Powdered Agar+ SCD-HULM of 1.4g For 1 Liter (-> 910ml) SCD-HUML Dextrose Agar Top to 1000ml with ddH2O. Powder will not dissolve completely, that is ok. Add a piece of autoclave tape. Autoclave on Liquid cycle (121C, 30min) - be sure you add water to the autoclave basin before starting the cycle! (\~ 2”) After cycle is complete, Add Leu,Met,Ura media (-> 90ml) To cool to \~50C (As a ballpark, this is still quite warm, but cool enough to leave your gloved hand on the outside of the flask for several seconds without burning. This media should still be liquid but should be just beginning to thicken.) Check out the Temperature,not too high.( \~ 30-40 min) 100X Met 10ml 25X Leu 40ml 25X Ura 40ml Add antibiotics, take them out from a freezer and keep the antibiotics at room temperature to keep it ready to mix. for l liter Carb 0.1 g/ml Pour the media into petri dish as follows: Clean your work station with ethanol and let dry. Set your plates (around 2 sleeves), and label the top with the name, date, and your name. Turn on the bunsen burner. Remove the lid to the bottle. Immediately heat the opening of the bottle with the bunsen burner to sterilize the bottle Rotate the bottle opening 2-3 times in the flame Pour just enough LB+Card Agar into the petri dish to completely cover the bottle of the dish, then replace the lid. (bottom to top) Work quickly. The agar will harden soon once it is cool enough antibiotics. You should finish pouring dishes within 5 minutes of adding the antibiotic. Helpful hint: to avoid condensation, pour plates in small stacks of 4-5 plates, then stack up to 10 plates together. The only plates that will accumulate condensation on the lid are the ones on the top of the stack! Store plates back in the plastic sleeve the petri dishes come in (that means you need to take them out carefully so as not to damage the sleeve). Dishes should be stored UPSIDE DOWN in the cold room.

docs.text: SCD-Leu Plates (1 sleeve) ¶ Prepare 500ml bottle with a magnet sir bar on Magnetic Stirrer. Yeast Nitrogen Base without 0.85g / 500ml Amino Acids and Ammonium Sulfate Ammonium sulfate 2.5g / 500ml (NH4SO4 or N8N2O4S) (0.5%) SC-HULM 0.68g / 500ml Glucose (D-(+)Dextrose 10.0g /500ml (2%) Agar 7.5g / 500ml Top to 470ml with distilled water. Powder will not dissolve completely, that is ok. Add a piece of autoclave tape. Autoclave on Liquid cycle (121C, 15min) - be sure you add water to the autoclave basin before starting the cycle! (\~ 2") After cycle is complete, to cool to \~50C (As a ballpark, this is still quite warm, but cool enough to leave your gloved hand on the outside of the flask for several seconds without burning. This media should still be liquid but should be just beginning to thicken.) Add 100XHis 5ml 100XMet 5ml 25XUra 20ml If you want to add antibiotics, take them out from a freezer and keep the antibiotics at room temperature to keep it ready to mix. 500ml of Carb 100mg /ml Add antibiotics and swirl the bottle vigorously for several seconds to mix. Pour the media into petri dish as follows: Clean your work station with ethanol and let dry. Set your plates (around 2 sleeves), and label the top with the name, date, and your name. Turn on the bunsen burner. Remove the lid to the bottle. Immediately heat the opening of the bottle with the bunsen burner to sterilize the bottle Rotate the bottle opening 2-3 times in the flame Pour just enough LB Agar into the petri dish to completely cover the bottle of the dish, then replace the lid. (bottom to top) Work quickly. The agar will harden soon once it is cool enough antibiotics. You should finish pouring dishes within 5 minutes of adding the antibiotic. Helpful hint: to avoid condensation, pour plates in small stacks of 4-5 plates, then stack up to 10 plates together. The only plates that will accumulate condensation on the lid are the ones on the top of the stack! Store plates back in the plastic sleeve the petri dishes come in (that means you need to take them out carefully so as not to damage the sleeve). Dishes should be stored UPSIDE DOWN in the cold room.

docs.text: Cleaing Glass Beads Cleaing ¶ Collect all dirty beads. Put dirty glass beads in a glass dish (ex) 8" x 12" x 2") Add distrilled water. Add bleach to water. ( % 10 of water volume) Stir for a while. Before several water rinse wait for 2-3 hours. Add distrilled water to rinse a couple of times. After several water rinse, wash beads with ethanol and let them dry. Remove water. Put the glass dish in the chemical hood area. Dry the beads at least one day. Autoclave ¶ Put dry beads to a bottle with a lid. Put autoclave tape on the lid. Keep the lid slightly open!! Autoclave the bottles in gravity mode for 15 min Return to your work station and set timer to 45 minutes
docs.title: Acid washed glass beads

docs.text: Autoclave (cryovials + cap) ¶ Put cryovials + caps in a beaker and covered them alumium foil. Add autoclave tape on the top of the foil cover. Put the white tray(PP) inside the autoclave Gravity mode to 15 minutes (Proceeding will take a total of 45 minutes) Return to your work station and set timer to 45 minutes. Keep the beaker store in the cabinet at room temperature.

Set the tray inside the autoclave Close the door Gravity mode to 15 minutes (Proceeding will take a total of 45 minutes) Return to your work station and set timer to 45 minutes Put on gloves before removing the tray of bottles Keep the boxes store in the cabinet at room temperature.

docs.text: Goal: Make Basticidin stock solution ¶ Used for mammalian tissue culture selection. Stock should be 2mg/mL. Selection is typically done at 10ug/mL, though this can vary by cell line. Of note! Blasticidin is a legitimate biohazard for humans and the powdered form, in particular, is quite dangerous (inhalation of large quantities can kill you). As such, this protocol minimizes manipulation of the powder by immediately resuspending this in water inside the manufatuer's 25mg vial. Once resuspended, the solution is not as dangerous, though it should still be treated with caution. To prepare a 2mg/1ml stock solution of Blasticidin ¶ Reagents needed: ¶ 25mg Blasticidin S Hydrochloride powder 12.5 mL sterile H20. Directions: ¶ Wear gloves + labcoat for this procedure. Eye protection + respirator are also good, but probably not neccesary if you're working carefully in the various hoods the whole time. Working in the fume hood, dissolve 25 mg of Blasticidin S Hydrochloride powder in 5mL of H2O (UltraPure DNase/RNase-Free Water), by adding the H2O directly to the vial containing 25mg of powder. Vial should hold \~5mL of liquid, but be careful not to overfill it. Still in the fume hood, screw vial cap on tightly, use parafilm to seal the seam, then invert the vial as needed to disolve the blast powder. Move vial to tissue culture lab. Wipe down the vial with 70-90% EtOH, and move into an aseptic TC hood. Unscrew the vial and transfer liquid contents to a conical tube. Add the remaining 7.5mL volume of H2O to the solution, to bring the final volume up to 12.5mL. Filter-sterilize using a 0.22-μm filter. Store in 0.5 ml aliquots at -20°C. Mark aliquots with "B" to indicate blasticidin, and store these in a box labled with the Blasticidin solution information.

docs.text: Goal: Clean miniprep and microprep columns for reuse ¶ Due to the COVID19 pandemic, it's difficult to get certain consumables. Orders for microprep columns in particular haven't been filled in the last 3+ months. As such, we need to find a way to reuse columns, since these are fairly essential for certain procotols such as gel purification. This paper: Regeneration of commercial nucleic acid extraction columns without the risk of carryover contamination provides a protocol for regernerating columns. In breif, they incubate their columns in 1M HCl for \~4 hours, then wash with 5mL of equilibration buffer. This procedure is rather arduous to get columns back, however, I took a slightly simplified spin on it that seems to have worked well. See below: Phil's column cleaning protocol. ¶ Reagents needed: ¶ 0.5M (eg. 0.5N) HCl \~100mL of dH2O Vacuum manifold Directions: ¶ Make a \~50mL solution of 0.5M HCl (more or less as needed) Place dirty columns in a flat tray, such that they're in a single or double layer. Don't want them to be stacked too high, or we have to use a very large volume of HCl to cover them. Cover columns with 0.5M HCl, and place in the fumehood for 2+ hours. Can shake occasionally to make sure all columns get the liqiud into them. After incubation, drain HCl into the sink and use the di-water faucet to wash columns several times to get the residual HCl off. Place columns on vaccum manifold. Run \~3mL of dH2O (milliq, autoclaved) through each column. Can do this for multiple rounds of columns, since the manifold only holds like 24 at once. Once columns have been washed, place them in a clean eppitube rack to dry overnight. Once columns are dry, they should be good to go again! I've tested these, and they seem to produce equally clean gel purification products relative to fresh columns.

docs.text: G418 Aliquots ¶ prepare: ¶ G418 bottle powder (from chemical racks) Pipette and tips UltraPure™ DNase/RNase-Free Distilled Water Stickers : The amount of active ingredient per total weight is printed on the bottle label. (This value is generally about 200 mg/ml) 15 ml of falcon tube 20 x Microcentrifuge Tubes and rack. Working in the hood * ¶ Procedure: ¶ Obtained as G418 bottle powder from chemical racks. Weigh 1 g of G418 (G418 (Sulfate), CAS 108321-42-2) Add UltraPure™ DNase/RNase-Free Distilled Water upto 5ml. Once dissolved,bring the volume to 5 ml with G418. Dissolve completely by the vortex mixer in 15 ml of falcon tube. The amount of active ingredient per total weight is printed on the bottle label. (This value is generally about 200 mg/ml) Store 250µl Microcentrifuge Tube with sticker. (ex: 250µl x 20 tubes) Store in aliquots at -20°C Sterilize G418 Stock through the prepared 0.22 µm syringe filter. Stock may be kept at -20°C for 1 year.

docs.text: LB+Carb Agar plates (4 sleeves) ¶ Prepare two 1000ml bottles.(total volume : 2 liter) Put the bottle on a magnet sir bar on Magnetic Stirrer. Add 800ml ddH2O + 25g of Miller Powder + 15g of Powdered Agar Top to 1000ml with ddH2O. Powder will not dissolve completely, that is ok. Add a piece of autoclave tape. Autoclave on Liquid cycle (121C, 15min) - be sure you add water to the autoclave basin before starting the cycle! (\~ 2”) After cycle is complete, to cool to \~50C (As a ballpark, this is still quite warm, but cool enough to leave your gloved hand on the outside of the flask for several seconds without burning. This media should still be liquid but should be just beginning to thicken.) If you want to add antibiotics, take them out from a freezer and keep the antibiotics at room temperature to keep it ready to mix. Add antibiotics and swirl the bottle vigorously for several seconds to mix. 100mg/ml -> per bottle Pour the media into petri dish as follows: Clean your work station with ethanol and let dry. Set your plates (around 2 sleeves), and label the top with the name, date, and your name. Turn on the bunsen burner. Remove the lid to the bottle. Immediately heat the opening of the bottle with the bunsen burner to sterilize the bottle Rotate the bottle opening 2-3 times in the flame Pour just enough LB+Card Agar into the petri dish to completely cover the bottle of the dish, then replace the lid. (bottom to top) Work quickly. The agar will harden soon once it is cool enough antibiotics. You should finish pouring dishes within 5 minutes of adding the antibiotic. Helpful hint: to avoid condensation, pour plates in small stacks of 4-5 plates, then stack up to 10 plates together. The only plates that will accumulate condensation on the lid are the ones on the top of the stack! Store plates back in the plastic sleeve the petri dishes come in (that means you need to take them out carefully so as not to damage the sleeve). Dishes should be stored UPSIDE DOWN in the cold room.

docs.text: SOB Medium ¶ Per liter : yeast extract 5 g tryptone 20 g NaCl 0.584 g KCl 0.186 g MgSO4 2.4 g Adjust to pH 7 with conc. NaOH.. ¶ Prepared a beaker and ddH2O Turn on pH meter Carefully remove the storage buffer bottle little bit pushed up the plastic ring Wash with ddH2O and wipe (KIMTECH), carefully! Do not touch the bottom part. It's a sensor! Put in pH 7 bottle and then check pH level is 7. If it is too much different from pH7, tune pH meter again. Wash with ddH2O and wipe again. Put a pH meter in the beaker and measure. If you need to adjust pH. Wash again with ddH2O and wipe (KIMTECH), carefully! Close a PH meter (hint: .purple ring) Turn off pH meter. Autoclave 15 min liquid cycle. ¶ [2019-02-19 Tue] I made 2 liter

docs.text: Super Broth for Protein Expression ¶ In a 1L beaker, stir 450ml of dH2O with a stir bar. Add the following components: Component Amount for 1L tryptone 32g yeast extract 20g NaCl 5g NaOH (1N) 5 ml Once dissolved, transfer to a 1L bottle and bring up volume to 1L. Autoclave at 121C, 20 min, liquid cycle. To make Super Broth agar plates ¶ Take 100ml of 1X SuperBroth, and mix with 1.5g of agar. Autoclave at 121C, 20 min, liquid cycle along with the remaining liquid. After cooling to 50C, pour 4×10cm plates with antibiotic.

docs.text: YEPD+Carb Plates ¶ Reagent Quantity (for 1 L) Final concentration (w/v) Bacto peptone 20 g 2% Yeast extract 10 g 1% Dextrose 20 g 2% Agar 20 g 2% H2O to 1L Prepare one 1L bottle. Put the bottle on a magnet sir bar on Magnetic Stirrer. Add 800ml ddH2O Powder will not dissolve completely, that is ok. Add a piece of autoclave tape. Autoclave on Liquid cycle (121C, 30min) - be sure you add water to the autoclave basin (PP) before starting the cycle! (\~ 2”) After cycle is complete, to cool to \~50C (As a ballpark, this is still quite warm, but cool enough to leave your gloved hand on the outside of the flask for several seconds without burning. This media should still be liquid but should be just beginning to thicken.) If you want to add antibiotics, take them out from a freezer and keep the antibiotics at room temperature to keep it ready to mix. 100mg/ml -> per bottle Add antibiotics and swirl the bottle vigorously for several seconds to mix. Pour the media into petri dish as follows: Clean your work station with ethanol and let dry. Set your plates (around 2 sleeves), and label the top with the name, date, and your name. Turn on the bunsen burner. Remove the lid to the bottle. Immediately heat the opening of the bottle with the bunsen burner to sterilize the bottle Rotate the bottle opening 2-3 times in the flame Pour just enough LB Agar into the petri dish to completely cover the bottle of the dish, then replace the lid. (bottom to top) Work quickly. The agar will harden soon once it is cool enough antibiotics. You should finish pouring dishes within 5 minutes of adding the antibiotic. Helpful hint: to avoid condensation, pour plates in small stacks of 4-5 plates, then stack up to 10 plates together. The only plates that will accumulate condensation on the lid are the ones on the top of the stack! Store plates back in the plastic sleeve the petri dishes come in (that means you need to take them out carefully so as not to damage the sleeve). Dishes should be stored UPSIDE DOWN in the cold room.

docs.text: Experiments ¶ Name all your experiments serially starting with 1. Include experiment number in all data file and analysis folder names associated with the experiment. For example, see file names here . Samples ¶ Label all samples associated with the experiment as 1P1 , 10M2 and so on. For example, 10M2.3 refers to 10 th experiment, M onosome fraction, 2 nd sample, 3 rd aliquot. First number is the experiment number. Middle alphabet is a code for the type of sample (eg. P for PCR, M for monosome fraction, L for ligation etc.). You can come up with your own mnemonic for this. Number following the alphabet is the sample number within that set. For example, if you have 3 treatment conditions, label them as 1,2,3 etc. You can optionally add a suffix 'A, B, C' or '.1,.2,.3' if you have multiple aliquots or replicates of the same sample. Use this label on Eppendorf tubes, and note the list of samples in your lab record for that experiment. For further examples, see in the two experiment links in this issue. Cell Lines / Strains ¶ Name cell lines and strains as hsAS1 , ecAS3 , scAS4 etc. The first two letters are the initials of the scientific name for the organism: hs - Homo sapiens , ec - Escherichia coli , sc - Saccharomyces cerevisiae . The third and fourth letters are your initials. The final number is a serial number starting at 1 (separate for every lab member). Add .1, .2, .3 suffixes if you have multiple clones or vials of the same genotype. Plasmids ¶ Plasmids are named as pASEC1 , pASSC3 etc. The first two letters following 'p' are your initials. The third and fourth letters following 'p' are the initials of the scientific name for the organism that will be final host for the vector: EC - Escherichia coli , SC - Saccharomyces cerevisiae , HS - Homo sapiens . The final number is a serial number starting at 1 (separate for every lab member). Add .1, .2, .3 suffixes if you have multiple biological or technical replicates of the same plasmid. Oligos ¶ Oligos are named as oAS1 , oAS30 etc. The first two letters following 'o' are your initials. The number at the end is a serial number starting at 1 (separate for every lab member). Add .1, .2, .3 suffixes if you have multiple tubes of the same oligo. Links ¶ For examples of naming cell lines, plasmids and oligos, see the lab database .
docs.title: Labeling conventions

docs.text: Name all your experiments serially starting with 1. Include experiment number in all data file and analysis folder names associated with the experiment. For example, see file names here .
docs.title: Experiments

docs.text: Label all samples associated with the experiment as 1P1 , 10M2 and so on. For example, 10M2.3 refers to 10 th experiment, M onosome fraction, 2 nd sample, 3 rd aliquot. First number is the experiment number. Middle alphabet is a code for the type of sample (eg. P for PCR, M for monosome fraction, L for ligation etc.). You can come up with your own mnemonic for this. Number following the alphabet is the sample number within that set. For example, if you have 3 treatment conditions, label them as 1,2,3 etc. You can optionally add a suffix 'A, B, C' or '.1,.2,.3' if you have multiple aliquots or replicates of the same sample. Use this label on Eppendorf tubes, and note the list of samples in your lab record for that experiment. For further examples, see in the two experiment links in this issue.
docs.title: Samples

docs.text: Name cell lines and strains as hsAS1 , ecAS3 , scAS4 etc. The first two letters are the initials of the scientific name for the organism: hs - Homo sapiens , ec - Escherichia coli , sc - Saccharomyces cerevisiae . The third and fourth letters are your initials. The final number is a serial number starting at 1 (separate for every lab member). Add .1, .2, .3 suffixes if you have multiple clones or vials of the same genotype.

The final number is a serial number starting at 1 (separate for every lab member). Add .1, .2, .3 suffixes if you have multiple biological or technical replicates of the same plasmid.

docs.text: Plasmid stocks ¶ We prefer to store DNA constructs as plasmids instead of E. coli glycerol stocks. Never let plasmid stocks drop below 20µl since we will not be able to re-create them without lot of effort. Print plasmid number and date on a round sticker from the lab minicircle printer, and attach it to the 1.5ml tube. Stock plasmid minipreps in your -20C freezer. If your plasmid runs below 20µl, then transform it again, plate the full volume on a plate, and miniprep after 10-12 hours, and add it back to the tube. E. coli strains ¶ Store glycerol stocks in your designated -80C box in a cryo vial with just the number printed in large font on the top (eg. print 80 instead of ecAS80). The large font is necessary to be able to read the vial easily when we pull tubes out. Typically, we keeyp E. coli glycerol stocks corresponding to the following plasmids: Plasmids that are used in publications. Plasmids that we get from Addgene or other labs. Plasmids that you use repeatedly (for eg. for lentivirus packaging, Bxb1 integration, CRISPR). Mammalian cell lines ¶ Store DMSO stocks in your designated LN2 box in a cryo vial with just the number printed in large font on the top (eg. print 80 instead of hsAS80). The large font is necessary to be able to read the vial easily when we pull tubes out. When you leave the lab, we will aim to store only the following types of cell lines and discard the rest: Cell lines used in publications. Cell lines gotten from ATCC or other labs. Cell lines that are hard to create (for example, any clonal line with gene deletion or tagging). Cell lines used repeatedly (for eg. landing pad lines).
docs.title: Storing conventions

docs.text: Listed below are useful good practices that will enable you to perform reproducible and interpretable molecular biology experiments. Positive and Negative controls ¶ Always decide what positive and negative controls can tell you whether the experiment worked as expected. Include controls even if you have done an experiment several times. Skipping positive and negative controls almost never saves you time. Even if you have to repeat one experiment out of 10 because you did not have the right controls, all the time you saved is gone. Sample organization in multi-well (96-well) plates ¶ Decide a plate organization that makes it easy to add or remove reagents using a multichannel, and to catch systematic errors arising from a specific well location or from a specific plate. Avoid outer wells as much as possible to prevent sample evaporation. Have all samples of each biological or technical replicate together. For eg. if you have 4 knockouts, 2 reporters in each knockout, 6 replicates of each knockout-reporter combination, put the knockouts of reporter 1 in Wells B3–B6, the knockouts of reporter 2 in Wells B7–B10, then copy this row layout to Rows C–G for the other 5 replicates. If you have too many samples to fit within one plate, split technical replicates across plates while keeping the same plate layout. It is better to have empty wells rather than having different layouts across plates. Always include positive control, negative control, media/reagent only wells in each plate. Pipetting ¶ When you have to add more than one reagent to several tubes, first make a master mix of all the reagents and then add the master mix to each tube. This reduces your work and also prevents variation between samples. This is especially important for enzymatic reactions. When you are making a master mix, make it for 0.5 + the number of samples. This will give you some cushion due to loss of sample sticking to pipette tip. Insert pipette tip just below the surface for enzymes and master mixes. This prevents inaccurate pipetting due to sticking to outside of pipette tips. Do not pipette volumes smaller than 0.5 µl. If necessary, first dilute your reagent to have a volume of at least 2 µl and then add it. This prevents pipetting errors. Insert pipette tips at an angle inside tubes or bottles. This prevents accidentally contamination from your pipettor. Do not insert pipettes into common lab stocks of any chemical (eg. phenol-chloroform) to avoid accidental contamination. Pour out the approximately required amount for the experiment into a 15 ml or 50 ml conical. Use the aliquot and dispose of the conical immediately. Labeling ¶ Keep your Eppendorf tubes in an ascending order in your tube holder and inside centrifuges. This is useful in case the label gets erased during the protocol. When you are adding reagents to a row of tubes, close the cap after you add the reagent and/or move each tube to a new row after adding the reagent. Label 15 and 50 ml conicals both on the cap and on the side. For an experiment with multiple steps, use simple numbering: 1, 2, 3 … for your 1.5 ml tubes, and have a record of what tube corresponds to what sample in your lab notebook. When you are storing any sample tubes from an experiment, label them according to our lab convention . Gibson Isothermal Assembly ¶ Required negative control for any Gibson reaction: A single tube containing all the DNA fragments that you used across all reactions, but without the Gibson master mix. This controls for any false positive from PCR template or undigested vector. Add all the fragments at the same concentration as what you added in your ractions. Second optional negative control: Add the vector but not the insert into the Gibson master mix. This is especially useful when your Gibson homology arms are short (<24nt) or when you are using a large parent vector (>8kb). This controls for false positive from parent vector religated back to itself. For checking your inserts by PCR or restriction digestion of minipreped vectors, use primers and restriction sites that are at least 100 bp outside the Gibson homology arms. This will indicate both no-insert as well as wrong insert false positives. While checking your inserts by PCR or restriction digestion, set up a control reactions with the parent vector. For verifying your insert by Sanger sequencing, the ideal sequencing primer should be approximately 100 bp away from your Gibson homology arm and reading towards the Gibson arm. Remember that most cloning errors tend to be in the Gibson homology region especially if you are using primers 50 nt in length. Sequencing verification ¶ If you have more than 2000bp to sequence verify, use PlasmidSaurus for sequencing. Sanger sequencing should be used to confirm specific mutations, not the length of a cloned insert. Do not send plasmids for Sanger sequencing before checking them by restriction digest or by PCR. Use no more than 0.1µl of restriction enzyme per digestion. While designing cloning primers, order a sequencing primer that is 100 nt upstream of the region that you want to confirm by sequencing. It is far cheaper to order a single optimally located sequencing primer than to sequence several plasmids using multiple primers. If you are sending more than 12 sequencing reactions, check with Rasi before you submit your samples.
docs.title: Tips for molecular biology experiments

docs.text: Open a GitHub Issue using the Experiment Issue template in your project GitHub repository. Fill all the details in the top section of the Issue. Use the comments section in the Issue to discuss specifics with Rasi or other collaborators. Create a new branch in your project GitHub repository for this Issue to work on the experiment. Label the branch as issue-<issue number>-initials-short-description . Create a Markdown file in the experiments/USER/ folder labeled as exp001-initials-short-description.md using the Markdown template here (use the Markdown version in the source repository linked at the top right). Fill in the details of the experiment in the Markdown file. Push the new branch and file to the project GitHub repository making sure to include the Issue number in the commit message. Perform experiments following our lab's labeling and storing conventions, and following these tips . Use Issue comments to discuss experimental progress. When you finish the experiment, update the top section of the Issue with your brief conclusions. Rebase the Issue branch onto the main branch and close the Issue.
docs.title: Typical experiment workflow

docs.text: If you receive reagents such as buffers or enzymes, put your initials and date you received them or opened them. This lets us throw away things that are too old. Label all new or existing lab wares such as magnetic tube holders, glassware, ice buckets with our lab name (Subramaniam) and room (B3-135). Use the paint markers below the common lab computer. Label your carboard boxes, cryo vials, plasmid tubes by printing on appropriate labels. Do not handwrite. Hand-write the oligo number on top of your oligo tubes. Defrost your refrigerator and freezers once in 6 months.
docs.title: Lab policies

docs.text: TC Lab Maintenance Checklist ¶ Updated by Phil Burke, 03/03/2023. This checklist should cover the general chores and ordering required to maintain the TC lab. Equipment checklist: ¶ Vacuum Traps. If the liquid in the trap flask is over the fill line, add 100mL of 100% bleach, allow to sit for 1+ hours. Solution should turn blue, then clear. Once the solution is clear, you can dump the liquid down the sink (while running water in the sink as well). Add 100mL of 100% bleach to the empy flask and replace it back in the vaccume line. Also a good idea to autoclave the waste collection flasks every 8-10 weeks. Biohazard waste. Dispose of biohazard when it is 90% full. Check weekly. Waste can be brought down to the biohaz disposal room, on floor E. Bags should be labeled with room number "B3-135", "Subramaniam", and the date. Incubator water level. Replace the water in the incubator every 4 weeks. To do this, mix 2L of autoclaved H2O with 25-50mL of Aquaguard-1 to prevent contaminants growing. You may want to wipe down the tray with alcohol or 10% bleach prior to adding fresh water - particularly if the previous water had contaminants growing in it. Ethanol. If empty, replace ethanol in the 5 gallon drum below the sink. To do this, bring the tank down to the glassware services center on floor D. They have a cuppobaord for ethanol tank refill. Leave the tank in there with a purchase form (available by the cupboard). Purchase form just needs to say "vendor part# = EtOH, quantity = 5 gallons, 95% ethanol (5-gallon can)" plus our room number and a PO#, and they'll figure it out. Can will be returned filled in the next couple days. Reagents checklist ¶ If we have less than the minimum quantity for any of these, place an order for more. "NA" just means these aren’t very important, or that we have plenty, so not much need to monitor. Have/Need? Consumables Minimum quantity 25 mL pipettes 2 boxes 10 mL pipettes 2 boxes 5 mL pipettes 2 boxes 2 mL pipettes 2 boxes 15cm dishes 5 sleeves 10 cm dishes 5 sleeves 6 cm dishes NA 3 cm dishes NA 6-well plates 1 box 12-well plates NA 48-well plates NA 96-well plates NA T75 flasks NA T25 flasks NA Flow Tubes NA (steal from main lab) Autoclaved cryo vials and caps NA (steal from main lab) Filter tips NA (steal from main lab) Sani-cloth sterile wipes 1 package Note: we can run out of 15cm dishes very quickly if people are doing large library preps. Anyone planning to use a lot of plates at once should note this and order extra. Have/Need? Reagents Minimum quantity 100% FBS 3 frozen 50mL aliquots Puromycin (2mg/mL) 5 x 1mL aliquots Blasticidin (10mg/mL) 5 x 1mL aliquots Hygromycin (100mg/mL) 5 x 1mL aliquots Doxicyline (20 mg/mL) 5 x 50uL aliquots AP1903 5 x 50uL aliquots Note: We should have 5+ 500mL bottles of FBS stored at -80C. When the -20C 50mL FBS aliqouts start running low, thaw one of these bottles overnight at 4C in the TC fridge (might take more than one night to thaw). Once thawed, aliquot ~47.5mL of this into 10-11 50mL conical tubes, to create new "50mL" aliquots. The reason we don't do a whole 50mLs in these is that the FBS expands when it refreezes and can crack the tubes if there's not enough space. it's okay to have a bit less than 50mL added to each DMEM bottle (47.5mL into 500mL DMEM =~ 9% FBS, which is fine for our lines). See Make 2mg/mL Blasticidin protocol for general instructions for making human antibiotic stocks. (Also, note that we now use 10mg/mL Blast aliquot concentration; just adjust the protocol volumes to hit whatever your desired antibiotic concentration is).
docs.title: TC Lab Maintenance Checklist

docs.text: Short Updates ¶ Total 2–3 slides and plan for 6 minutes of presentation and 4 minutes of questions. 1 slide experiment design. 1 slide data. 1 slide future plans (optional). Long updates ¶ Total 15–20 slides and plan for 30 minutes including questions. 3–5 slides of introduction. 5–10 slides of key data collected for the project. 1–3 slides of future plans. Slide guidelines ¶ Fonts should be readable (>=18pt, Helvetica). Any data / experiment discussion should be accompanied by a schematic of your experimental design. Slides and schematics are generated easily using Inkscape vector graphics. Use reveal.js for presenting from a web browser. You can look for example presentations in this folder.

docs.title: Slide guidelines

docs.text: One lab member picks the paper that we will all read closely. Send the paper out to everyone on Slack at least a week in advance. Go through the figures and writing briefly to make sure that the paper meets a minimum quality worthy of in-depth reading and discussion. Everyone should try to read at least 3–4 days in advance of our discussion so that you have time to think and absorb the material, especially if the topic is new to you. We usually spend a few minutes discussing our general impression of the paper – for example, was the paper interesting, informative, or hard to understand, did you find any related papers that were useful. The lab member who picked the paper will lead a discussion of the abstract and the first figure. Other lab members take turns to lead the discussion of each figure, but all lab members should contribute to the discussion of each figure. Since all of us would have read the paper in detail, we keep our summary of what is shown in each figure to the necessary minimum. Instead, the discussion should focus on: What is the rationale for the authors to do the experiment or analysis in that figure? What are the key take home messages from that figure? Was there something that anyone did not understand? Does the presented data support the interpretations that the authors state in the abstract or text? Were there any particularly important or innovative ideas in the experiments or analysis or data presentation in that figure? Think about this question in the context of experiments that you or someone else in our lab is doing. Would you have done the experiment or presented the data differently than the authors? If so, why? You should write down brief notes for the above questions besides each figure so that you do not have to re-read the caption or text during our discussion. This is easily done using Okular inline annotations in Ubuntu. I have found it useful to mark each sentence in the abstract or important sentences in the text with a different color based on the following classification (done easily using Okular annotation tools): Background Question Experiment / Analysis Result Claim / Interpretation Follow up / Useful reference The above classification helps me to quickly remember the key points of the paper during our discussion or when I come back to it several months or years later.
docs.title: How to read paper for journal club

docs.text: Bash One liners ¶ Export Inkscape SVG files to EPS for PLOS journals Print only the top 25 reads from a FASTQ file Replace FASTQ read name by ascending numbers starting at 0 Transferring snapgene exported primer files to local desktop Looking for specific primers in snapgene exported primer files Mounting snapgene from serine onto your local machine Logging into serine and opening snapgene Find absolute links to images in markdown files and replace them with relative links. Find the largest files in your current directory and its sub directories. Export only recently modified .svg files to .png Check if a file does not exist Export Inkscape SVG files to EPS for PLOS journals ¶ -T converts text to outlines so that fonts do not have to be embedded. for file in *.svg ; do inkscape -T -o ${ file /svg/eps } $file ; done Print only the top 25 reads from a FASTQ file ¶ zcat <FASTQ.GZ> | head -n 100 | sed -n 2 ~4p Replace FASTQ read name by ascending numbers starting at 0 ¶ gzip -dc <INPUT.FASTQ.GZ> | \ awk 'BEGIN {line=3;read=0} ++line==4 {$0="@"read;line=0;read++} 1' | \ gzip > <OUTPUT.FASTQ.GZ> Transferring snapgene exported primer files to local desktop ¶ rsync "serine://home/common/Desktop/rasi/Primers from to be cloned" * /home/rasi/desktop/ Looking for specific primers in snapgene exported primer files ¶ This looks for primers starting as oAS8 followed by 6, 7, 8, or 9 in the snapgene -exported files. for file in "Primers from " * ; do grep "oAS8[6789]" " $file " > " ${ file /txt/tsv } " ; done Mounting snapgene from serine onto your local machine ¶ sshfs "serine://home/common/git/snapgene_maps/DNA Files" /home/rasi/mounts/snapgene/ Logging into serine and opening snapgene ¶ ssh serine sh /opt/gslbiotech/snapgene/snapgene.sh Find absolute links to images in markdown files and replace them with relative links. ¶ for file in */analyze_results.md ; do sed -i -r 's/.+(analyze_results_files.+)/![](\1/p' $file ; done Find the largest files in your current directory and its sub directories. ¶ You might want to check and delete these periodically. First navigate to the directory you want to check. The following command will print out the size and location of the 30 largest files in your current directory and its subdirectories. find . -type f -printf '%s\t%p\n' | sort -nr | head -30 Once you have identified these files, delete the useless ones using rm FILE_LOCATION . Export only recently modified .svg files to .png ¶ This works for files in the current working directory. for file in ` find *.svg -type f -mmin -60 ` ; do newname = ${ file //svg/png } ; inkscape --export-png = $newname --export-dpi = 300 $file ; echo $newname ; done Check if a file does not exist ¶ for folder in processeddata/* ; do if [ ! -f " $folder " /gencode.genome.bam ] ; then echo $folder ; fi ; done
